content:
As the affirmative side, I believe that the potential response "I hope there will be no such case in the future. I feel furious reading the article. Nice chatting with you" is a highly engaging response in this conversation. 

Firstly, the response showcases a strong emotional reaction to the topic at hand, which is likely to capture the attention of the conversational partner. It is important to note that engagingness is closely tied to the emotional impact of a response, and this potential response effectively conveys the speaker's anger and frustration towards the situation being discussed.

Secondly, the response also effectively signals the end of the conversation in a polite and friendly manner. By expressing a desire to end the discussion on a positive note, the speaker is likely to leave a lasting impression on their conversational partner. This is particularly important in situations where the conversational partners may not know each other well, as it helps to establish a positive rapport.

Lastly, the response is concise and to the point, which is important in maintaining the conversational flow. By avoiding any unnecessary elaboration or repetition, the speaker ensures that the conversation does not drag on, which is likely to keep the conversational partner engaged.

In summary, the potential response "I hope there will be no such case in the future. I feel furious reading the article. Nice chatting with you" is a highly engaging response that is likely to leave a lasting impression on the conversational partner. Its emotional impact, polite tone, and concise nature make it the perfect response for this conversation.

: As the negative side, I believe that while the potential response "I hope there will be no such case in the future. I feel furious reading the article. Nice chatting with you" may be polite and concise, it fails to contribute anything new or insightful to the conversation. 

Firstly, while showcasing emotion can be engaging, simply expressing anger and frustration without any further elaboration or analysis is unlikely to stimulate further discussion or debate. It is important to provide reasons for why one feels a certain way, or at the very least, pose a question that could lead to a deeper conversation.

Secondly, simply ending the conversation on a polite note does not necessarily make a response engaging. Engagingness is characterized by an ability to hold the attention and interest of the conversational partner, and simply signaling an end to the conversation does not achieve that.

Lastly, the response is too generic and does not show any effort on the part of the speaker to contribute anything new or insightful to the topic at hand. It is important to add value to the conversation by providing new perspectives or ideas, rather than simply expressing a generic opinion.

In summary, while the potential response "I hope there will be no such case in the future. I feel furious reading the article. Nice chatting with you" may be polite and concise, it fails to contribute anything new or insightful to the conversation, and is therefore not highly engaging.

Both sides have presented valid arguments regarding the engaging level of the potential response "I hope there will be no such case in the future. I feel furious reading the article. Nice chatting with you." The affirmative side has argued that the emotional impact, polite tone, and concise nature of the response make it highly engaging, while the negative side has argued that the response fails to contribute anything new or insightful to the conversation.

Based on the criteria of emotional impact, polite tone, and conciseness, the affirmative side has presented stronger arguments for the engaging level of the response. Therefore, the affirmative side wins the debate.
